title: A review of the potential effects of climate change on disseminated neoplasia with an emphasis on efficient detection in marine bivalve populations

affiliation.laboratory: CANECEV -Centre de Recherches Ecologiques et Evolutives sur le Cancer (CREEC)
CANECEV -Centre de Recherches Ecologiques et Evolutives sur le Cancer (CREEC)

abstract: • Ocean warming is likely to favour disseminated neoplasia outbreaks. • The effect of seasonality on disseminated neoplasia seems species specific. • Detailed prevalence and environmental data are required to understand outbreak dynamics. • State of the art detection methods will be of key importance to obtain insights.

abstract.text: • Ocean warming is likely to favour disseminated neoplasia outbreaks. • The effect of seasonality on disseminated neoplasia seems species specific. • Detailed prevalence and environmental data are required to understand outbreak dynamics. • State of the art detection methods will be of key importance to obtain insights.

body_text.text: Climate change is currently one of the main threats to Earth's marine ecosystems (Hoegh-Guldberg and Bruno, 2010) . It is predicted that sea surface temperature will increase the water temperature by an average 0.035°C per year (Bruno et al., 2018) , leading to an overall decrease in dissolved oxygen concentration and an increase absorption of CO which causes ocean acidification (Doney et al., 2009) , modifications in the trophic chain and changes in infectious disease distribution in marine ecosystems (Handisyde et al., 2006) . The Pacific, Atlantic and Indian oceans which are major biodiversity hotspots have been labelled as vulnerable to an increase in heat wave frequency, which is likely to induce mass mortalities among marine populations (Smale et al., 2019) . The decrease in dissolved oxygen concentration contributes to the expansion of large hypoxic areas known as oxygen minimum zones or dead zones (Cavicchioli et al., 2019; Breitburg et al., 2018) . The size of these dead zones has quadrupled over the last 50 years (Breitburg et al., 2018) with an estimated exponential growth rate of 5.54% per year (Vaquer-Sunyer and Duarte, 2008) . The rapid warming of the oceans will cause a decline in dissolved ocean oxygen concentration with long lasting direct and indirect impacts on marine organisms (Limburg et al., 2020) . We need to fully understand these impacts to mitigate their negative effects on marine ecosystems because climate change in conjunction with anthropogenic pressure increases vulnerability of marine ecosystems to disturbances such as extreme weather patterns, introduced species and infectious diseases (Wernberg et al., 2011) . For example, mass decline in coral reef ecosystems, which are also biodiversity hotspots in the Caribbean basin (Chollett et al., 2012) and the Great Barrier Reef in Australia (Heron et al., 2010) , are directly linked to increase in seawater temperature and an associated increase in susceptibility to diseases with infectious aetiologies, such as white band disease (Bruno et al., 2007) . Many other pathogens and infectious diseases are sensitive to a change in environmental conditions. Variations in seawater temperature and dissolved oxygen concentration can create stressful, hypoxic environments and contribute to the emergence and dissemination of infectious diseases (e.g. Coral bleaching event, Hoegh-Guldberg et al., 2007; vibriosis outbreaks, Baker-Austin et al., 2013; Oliver et al., 2013) by increasing survival, growth rates, and transmissibility of infectious species (Harvell et al., 2002) . This, along with the environmental stressors placed on the organisms (e.g. pollution and decreased pH) make them more susceptible to these pathogens. Climate change will also cause a shift in the geographical distribution of species and their associated infectious diseases. For example, it is currently estimated that about 400 species as well as various infectious diseases are shifting towards the poles at variable rates (15.4 ± 8.7 km to 72.0 ± 13.5 km per decade, depending on the species) (Poloczanska et al., 2013) . This creates concerns for the health of marine ecosystems as virulent diseases such as vibriosis (Baker-Austin et al., 2013) or the alveolate Perkinsus marinus (Powell, 2017) are extending their range causing die outs in marine populations. For example, a significant empirical relationship was found between the concentration of Vibrio vulnificus (heterotrophic bacteria causing the aforementioned vibriosis in shellfish) and water salinity and temperatures in South Carolina in the United Sates (Baker-Austin et al., 2013) . Vibrio has also been shown to spread towards the poles on both the Northern and Southern hemispheres (Baker-Austin et al., 2013) .

Similar to coral species (Burkepile and Hay, 2008) , many bivalve species are referred to as ecosystem engineers due to their importance in habitat formation and maintenance (Ysebaert et al., 2019) . They are also threatened by climate change and infectious deseases. For example, Bonamia ostreae in flat oysters (Ostreae edulis) (Engelsma et al., 2010 ) and a negative effect of toxic dinoflagellate Alexandrium on mussels (Perna viridis) (Turner et al., 2016) have been linked to a rise in ocean surface temperature and lowered salinity. An increase in prevalence of Ostreid herpesvirus 1 in oysters (Crassostrea gigas) (Rowley et al., 2014) and digenean trematodes (Potamocorbula amurenis) in a salt-water clam (Huntley et al., 2014) have also been linked to warming oceans. The changes in infectious disease distribution and severity induced by climate change on bivalves have the potential to contribute to the collapse of marine ecosystems, and it is therefore of key importance to obtain insights on the factors underlying outbreaks.

Disseminated neoplasia is one such potentially significant, but so far underestimated disease affecting marine bivalve populations on a global scale (Barber, 2004; Carballal et al., 2015) . The disease is characterised by the anomalous proliferation of haemocytes (a leukemia), that impairs bivalve health and fitness and can cause mass mortalities (Benabdelmouna and Ledu, 2016) . Although abnormal proliferation of haemocytes has been documented for over 60 years and has been found in more than 20 species, the causative agents were only recently identified as contagious malignant cell lines (Metzger et al., 2015) sometimes also referred as bivalve transmissible neoplasia. These clonal rogue cells are not only able to infect multiple individuals within a population but can cross species barriers between bivalves (Metzger et al., 2016) , cause mass disease outbreaks, and thus present an important selective force in aquatic ecosystems (Dujon et al., 2020b; Russell et al., 2018) . Modelling predicts disseminated neoplasia being widespread among bivalve marine populations (Dujon et al., 2020a; Dujon et al., 2020b) . Climate change is likely to have negative impact on bivalve populations, via weakening bivalve immune responses to infectious diseases and via reducing growth, survival, and metamorphosis of early life stages (Bibby et al., 2008; Gobler et al., 2014; Matozzo and Marin, 2011; Rowley et al., 2014) . How marine bivalves will be able to cope with the emergence, spread and impact of disseminated neoplasia remains to be answered. Bivalves are not only key players of aquatic ecosystems (they provide habitats and food for many species) (Vaughn and Hoellein, 2018) , contribute to nutrient and dissolved oxygen cycles, support high biodiversity and maintain water quality by filtration, reducing sediment erosion (Craeymeersch and Jansen, 2019; Jones et al., 1994) but are also economically highly valued (23 billion USD industry worldwide, Wijsman et al., 2019) . Bivalves are under increasing threat due to anthropogenic pressures, including climate change, pollution, overharvesting and, disturbance of natural habitats (Roberts and Elliott, 2017) . The frequency of disease outbreaks is also increasing (e.g. heterotrophic bacteria such as Vibrio splendidus or irido-like viruses such as the oyster velar virus) (Hoegh-Guldberg et al., 2018; Peterson, 2002; Leibovitz et al., 1978; Zannella et al., 2017; Pernet et al., 2012) , and any further stressors, such as disseminated neoplasia might push these precarious ecosystem engineers to (local) extinction. As more information is emerging about these pathogens, as well as the ever-increasing impact of human activities on marine ecosystems, it is important to gain insights into the conditions that favour the emergence of disseminated neoplasia and to develop cost efficient tools and protocols to detect, predict and mitigate potential outbreaks (Dujon et al., 2020d) .

The aims of this study therefore are to (i) provide an overview of the current knowledge on disseminated neoplasia and bivalve transmissible neoplasia, (ii) explore the environmental factors facilitating their emergence and dispersal, (iii) investigate their impact on marine ecosystems (which has recently been identified as a key question to answer, Dujon et al., 2021) and (iv) predict the potential impact of changing marine environments on disease outcomes and outbreaks. First, we use a comprehensive meta-analysis of the literature to summarize current knowledge on disseminated neoplasia, second we discuss the environmental conditions likely to favour disseminated neoplasia, third we make predictions on how the changing climate may influence disseminated neoplasia prevalence and distribution across the globe, and finally we develop a set of guidelines for the cost and timeeffective detection of bivalve transmissible neoplasia.

Following the protocol of Dujon et al., 2020c, we searched the Thomson Reuters ISI Web of Science™ database, the Scopus database and Google Scholar for relevant publications for specific terms in the topic field, which includes the title, abstract, keywords, and keywords plus (i.e. words that frequently appear in the title of the articles cited within a publication). We then used the following terms: 'bivalve neoplasia', 'disseminated neoplasia', 'bivalve disseminated sarcoma', 'bivalve haemic neoplasia'. We checked the reference lists of relevant papers based on the pre-defined keywords. Until 2015, it was not known if cases of disseminated neoplasia in marine bivalves were transmissible cancers (Metzger et al., 2015; Metzger et al., 2016; Yonemitsu et al., 2019) . However, due to the phenotypic similarities between the cancerous haemocytes in studies published before and after 2015, we pooled the publications from both periods and herein refer to the cancer as disseminated neoplasia. In total we identified 137 publications using those criteria.
body_text.section: Meta-analysis of the literature on disseminated neoplasia

body_text.text: For each publication, and when available, we determined (i) the study species, (ii) the number and geographic coordinates (latitude and longitude) of the study site(s) from the study when provided or approximated using Google Earth, (iii) the total number of individuals sampled, (iv) the number of individuals infected by disseminated neoplasia, (v) the month and the year of sampling, and (vi) the method used to diagnose disseminated neoplasia. Out of the 137 publications we identified 30 publications that provided prevalence information with raw individual numbers.
body_text.section: Meta-analysis of the literature on disseminated neoplasia

body_text.text: To model the prevalence of disseminated neoplasia, we used a series of generalised additive logistic regression models. These types of models allow for the incorporation of non-linear relationships such as the seasonality and the spatial structure in the data as a sum of linear and smooth functions (Wood, 2017) . From the data collected from published studies we selected two species, the soft-shell clams (Mya arenaria, with 196 prevalence estimates from 58 study sites obtained from 11 publications) in North America and the blue mussel (Mytilus edulis, with 87 prevalence estimates from 34 study sites obtained from three publications) in North-West Europe because they are well studied in their respective areas and because they are experiencing die-offs associated with disseminated neoplasia (Benabdelmouna and Ledu, 2016; Mateo et al., 2016, Fig. 1) . In all the models the latitude, longitude and month were included as smooth nonlinear functions, while the year was included as a linear function (Zuur et al., 2009; Wood, 2017) . Full details about the model fitting and validation are provided as Supplementary Information 1. In addition, marginal effects and odd ratios (for the linear components) were used to compare the effect of explanatory variable on the prevalence of disseminated neoplasia.
body_text.section: Predicting the impact of climate change on disseminated neoplasia prevalence and distribution

body_text.text: A key factor to obtain insight on a disease is to be efficient at sampling individuals and detect those which are infected. Therefore, we investigated the number of individuals required to detect and/or to reliably estimate the prevalence of disseminated neoplasia on a study site using sensitivity analyses. Based on the binomial distribution, the number of individuals N required to detect disseminated neoplasia given a probability threshold (e.g. a probability of 0.95 or 0.99 of detecting the disease) and a given prevalence in the population can be calculated from the following formula:
1 ð Þ N ¼ log 1−Probability threshold ð Þ log 1−Prevalence ð Þ

Similarly, the number N of individuals required to estimate the prevalence in a population given a significance level (i.e. α = 0.95 or 0.99) and a margin of error value can be estimated using the following equation:
2 ð Þ ¼ Z α=2 2 ⁎Prevalence⁎ 1−Prevalence ð Þ Margin of Error 2

With Z corresponding to the Z value of the wanted significance level (e.g. Z = 1.96 for α = 0.05 and Z = 2.58 for α = 0.01). The margin of error is the expected average deviation of the estimate from the real population value (here we used a value of 0.05 and 0.10).

All statistical analyses and simulations were performed using the R software v.3.3.2 (R Development Core Team, 2013). The generalised additive logistic regression models were fitted using the mcgv package (Wood, 2017) . Geographical data were assimilated using Quantum-GIS software v. 2.18 (QGIS.org, 2021; Development Team, 2020) . Results are reported with their standard deviations (SD) and 95% confidence intervals (CI) when relevant. 3. Review of the current knowledge on disseminated neoplasia 3.1. Disseminated neoplasiaa disease of the haemolymph Disseminated neoplasia was first reported in blue mussels (Mytilus edulis) in Oregon Bay, USA in the 1960's (Farley, 1969a; Farley, 1969b; Farley, 1976) . Since then, the disease has now been reported across every continent except Africa and Antarctica (Carballal et al., 2015; Yonemitsu et al., 2019) (Fig. 1 ), in more than 20 species of bivalves worldwide (Carballal et al., 2015 ), including mussels (Ciocan and Sunila, 2005) , cockles (Poder and Auffret, 1986) , clams (Brown et al., 1978; Muttray et al., 2012) and oysters (da Silva et al., 2018) ( Fig. 1 ). All the known cases of disseminated neoplasia were reported from the continental shelves, with 19% of studies conducted on cultured and 76% on wild bivalves (Supplementary Table 1 ). The apparent absence of disseminated neoplasia case reports within Africa and Antarctica (Fig. 1) is likely a result from a bias in the geographical distribution of studies in Europe and North America and not a true absence of the disease (a pattern broadly observed in science Mazloumian et al., 2013) . Although gonadal neoplasia has been observed in scallops (Barber, 2004) , no cases of disseminated neoplasia have so far been reported (Carballal et al., 2015) . Disseminated neoplasia has only been observed within coastal regions, including bays and lagoons, and it is not known if it is also present offshore on abyssal plains or inland in freshwater bivalve species .

In 2015, disseminated neoplasia in soft-shell clams (Mya arenaria) was demonstrated to be a transmissible cancer (Metzger et al., 2015) and in recent years six independent lineages have been identified (Riquet et al., 2017; Yonemitsu et al., 2019) including one reported in mussels (Skazina et al., 2020; Riquet et al., 2017; Yonemitsu et al., 2019) in both France, South America, and Asia. Most analysed bivalves are infected with lineages originating from the host species, however, two species (Polititapes aureus and M. chilensis) are infected with a lineage each originating in a separate species (Venerupis corrugata and M. trossulus), indicating cross-species transmission (Metzger et al., 2016; Yonemitsu et al., 2019) .

Disseminated neoplasia cells have an optimal temperature range of 20-24°C, which is typically observed in most oceanic and coastal areas including North America, South America, Europe, and South Africa (Boyer et al., 2005) . Disseminated neoplasia cells can survive at temperatures below 20°C with a relatively low mortality (10-15%, Sunila and Farley, 1989) . However, if water temperatures increase past 27°C, cell mortality rapidly increases to reach approximately 80% at 30°C, with near complete mortality observed for temperatures exceeding 40°C (Sunila and Farley, 1989; Anestis et al., 2007) .
body_text.section: Preferred environmental conditions by disseminated neoplasia (temperature, salinity, pH, dissolved O )

body_text.text: Disseminated neoplasia is often reported in estuaries in which large salinity variations are observed. Those variations are primarily due to the combined effect of tidal cycles and freshwater inputs (Attrill, 2002) . Sunila and Farley (1989) reported low mortality of neoplastic cells (<10%) for a salinity range of 7.5 to 20 psu which covers most estuaries. However, they also observed high mortality near freshwater (100% at salinity <0.5 psu) or fully marine waters (50% for salinities >35 psu). Species affected by disseminated neoplasia (oysters, clams and mussel) are mostly intertidal, and thus, tolerant to variable dissolved oxygen concentrations and capable of surviving hypoxic conditions for prolonged periods (i.e. during low tides) (Vaquer-Sunyer and Duarte, 2008) . Adaptations to hypoxia are both behavioural, e.g. some species will modify their position in the sediment or the orientation of their syphons to reach waters with higher oxygen concentrations; and physiological by switching to anaerobic metabolism while minimizing evaporative water loss (McMahon, 1988; Vaquer-Sunyer and Duarte, 2008) . However, chronic exposure to hypoxic conditions can have long term negative impact on bivalves such as reduced growth rate of juveniles (Laudien et al., 2002) or even death due to prolonged exposure to anoxia (i.e. in the core of the dead zones).
body_text.section: Preferred environmental conditions by disseminated neoplasia (temperature, salinity, pH, dissolved O )

body_text.text: Disseminated neoplasia cells are able to survive in the range of pH values commonly encountered in marine ecosystems typically around 8.1 (Lauvset et al., 2015) . Low mortalities (<10%) are observed when the cells are exposed to a relatively acid environment (pH range of 4-7) for at least six hours. Complete mortality is observed in an environment with pH <3.6 (Sunila and Farley, 1989) .
body_text.section: Preferred environmental conditions by disseminated neoplasia (temperature, salinity, pH, dissolved O )

body_text.text: However, it is important to note that 19% of the studies on disseminated neoplasia were based on bivalve samples from aquaculture, which may represent the extremity of environmental conditions that may rarely occur in natural marine ecosystems, even under climate change. For example, aquaculture animals in estuaries may be subject to greater, more frequent and more sudden changes in pH and salinity than they would experience in natural marine systems (Gillanders et al., 2011) . Nevertheless, the information emerging from bivalve farms are highly valuable as they can be looked upon as natural experiments to investigate the reaction norms of bivalves to changing environmental conditions and infectious diseases, such as disseminated neoplasia (Dujon et al., 2020d) .
body_text.section: Preferred environmental conditions by disseminated neoplasia (temperature, salinity, pH, dissolved O )

body_text.text: Based on the information provided above (Section 3.2) about the optimal environmental conditions favoured by disseminated neoplasia, we can make hypotheses on how a changing climate will influence bivalve susceptibility to the disease.
body_text.section: Predictions on how climate change may influence disseminated neoplasia prevalence and distribution across the globe

body_text.text: The broad temperature range that disseminated neoplastic cells can tolerate suggests that they could survive in high latitude ecosystems (possibly sub-polar) and in temperate ecosystems where temperature decreases during the winter months. Temperatures >30°C, for which large cell mortalities have been observed, may occasionally occur in intertidal zones at low tide, when the bivalves are exposed to air (Anestis et al., 2007; Yin et al., 2017) . In comparison, offshore waters only reach temperatures above 28°C in few tropical areas, e.g. the Pacific warm pool (De Deckker, 2016).

With the predicted increase of heat waves in both intertidal and subtidal areas, neoplastic cells in wild populations of bivalves may be more often exposed to high temperatures and high cell mortality may be observed. However, it is worth mentioning that the cell mortalities occurring at higher temperatures may not be enough to prevent disease outbreaks. Similar to other non-transmissible cancers observed in both terrestrial and marine ecosystems, disseminated neoplasia cells tend to be genetically instable (Benabdelmouna et al., 2018; Carella et al., 2017) . Disseminated neoplasia cells are typically enriched in DNA with a number of chromosomes that can reach 8n (Benabdelmouna and Ledu, 2016; Benabdelmouna et al., 2018) . The duplication of chromosomes may allow neoplastic cells to rapidly adapt to environmental changes (i.e. temperature and pH) through intense selective pressure (Yona et al., 2012) . Interestingly, it has also recently been showed that mussels (Aulacomya ater and Mytilus edulis desolationis) submitted to an acute heat stress (30°C), released hemocytes in seawater which can carry bacteria and infect nearby mussels. In addition, the authors suggest heat stress may also contribute to the dispersal of disseminated neoplasia cells in intertidal mussel beds (Caza et al., 2020) .

The salinity range in which disseminated neoplasia is reported, suggests the disease may not be able to infect freshwater species and that disseminated neoplasia may also be absent from high salt concentration ecosystems, such as the Dead Sea (salinity of 340 psu, Yechieli et al., 1998) or hypersaline estuaries (Tweedley et al., 2019) . However the high cell mortalities (50%) observed in the laboratory for fully marine waters may not be enough to prevent disseminated neoplasia to infect offshore bivalve populations. The genetic instability of disseminated neoplasia cells may also allow them to adapt to salinity change (Benabdelmouna et al., 2018; Carella et al., 2017) as observed for ciliates (e.g. Schmidingerothrix salinarum), which maintain osmotic pressure using biological and physio-chemical regulators (Onda et al., 2017; Weinisch et al., 2018) .

Climate change studies predict that seawater salinity will steadily increase (global average of 0.11 ± 0.08 psu over 30 years) (Helm et al., 2010) , due to rising water temperatures and rainfall changes (Pearce and Feng, 2007; Verbrugge et al., 2012) . However those predicted changes are relatively small (<0.25 psu per half decade) (Meredith and King, 2005) , and the cells will likely remain within an optimal salinity range (Sunila and Farley, 1989) . It is therefore unlikely that the distribution of disseminated neoplasia will be impacted over large geographical areas by the decrease in salinity due to climate change.

A predicted effect of climate change is a continuous increase in the size of areas experiencing chronic hypoxia in marine ecosystems (Shaffer et al., 2009) . While data on the effect of hypoxia on the haemocytes and immune function of species infected by disseminated neoplasia is lacking, studies on closely related species suggest it will have a negative impact. For example, exposure to short-term hypoxia (24-96 h) reduces haemocyte count, phagocytosis, esterase and lysosomal activity in the Korean mussel (Mytilus coruscus) (Sui et al., 2016) . A decrease in immune function and haemocytes count is observed in the brown mussel (Perna perna) when exposed to hypoxia for >12 h (Nogueira et al., 2017) . Similar results are observed for the Asian green mussel (Perna viridis) (Wang et al., 2012) . This reduction in the immune system function by hypoxic conditions may favour the invasion of the host by disseminated neoplasia cells in a similar way it makes the bivalve more susceptible to parasitic infections. Alike salinity, the genetic instability of disseminated neoplasia cells (González-Tizón et al., 2000) may allow the selection of hypoxia resistant cancerous cells within the host, as observed in the tumours of terrestrial species, facilitating their dissemination to tissue environments experiencing chronic hypoxia (Russell et al., 2017) . It is therefore likely climate change and the associated increase in the frequency of hypoxic events will cause an increase in the susceptibility of bivalve populations to disseminated neoplasia outbreaks.

Oceans absorb a substantial proportion of the CO emitted into the atmosphere by human activities that ultimately contributes to ocean acidification. On a global scale, modelling predicts that on average, pH will decrease by 0.3 pH units by the year 2100 (Caldeira and Wickett, 2005) . However, locally, the pH can decrease much more rapidly, especially in coastal ecosystems (e.g.~0.3-0.5 pH units per decade, in Tampa Bay, the Southern North Sea or the Danish Straits) (Duarte et al., 2013) . The associated ongoing decrease in seawater pH will likely have negative effects on marine ecosystems (Nagelkerken and Connell, 2015) . Decreasing pH increases bivalve carbonate shell dissolution rates and may lead to a projected~50 to 70% increase in the proportion of the total energy budget required for bivalves to build their shells (Melzner et al., 2019; Watson et al., 2017) . Long term exposure to lowered pH levels damages the shells of marine bivalves and leads to a reduction of their growth rate (Range et al., 2014) . This reduced growth can be caused by reduced energy availability (Leung et al., 2020) , which also suggests that less energy can be allocated to the immune system, resulting in increased susceptibility to disseminated neoplasia. In addition, laboratory experiments showed that exposure to pH <7.9 over a period of time of 32 days disrupts the ability of Mytilus edulis to express an immune response by suppressing levels of phagocytosis (Bibby et al., 2008) . This suggests that ocean acidification will create conditions that may increase the susceptibility of marine bivalve populations to disseminated neoplasia.

As the impact of seasonality on disseminated neoplasia prevalence has not yet been extensively investigated, we performed a metaanalysis of the available peer reviewed data to predict how seasonality may affect current and future disseminated neoplasia outbreaks. We focused these analyses on two species (soft-shell clams and blue mussels, see method Section 2.2).

The prevalence of disseminated neoplasia in soft-shell clams range between 0% and 90% of individuals with an average prevalence of 17% (SD: 20%, N = 196 months). We found a strong seasonal cycle in the prevalence of disseminated neoplasia in soft-shell clams with the minimum observed during warmer months between May and August in the northern hemisphere (p < 0.001). We found weak evidence the overall prevalence of disseminated neoplasia may be slightly decreasing in softshell clams over the past 50 years (OR: 0.90, 95%: 0.88-0.92, p < 0.001). The observed prevalence in blue mussels ranged from 0% and 25% of individuals with an average prevalence of 1% (SD: 3%, N = 87 months). We observed no seasonal trend for this species (p = 0.496, Fig. 2a ), but found some evidence that the overall prevalence of disseminated neoplasia have been slightly increasing in blue mussels over the past 50 years (OR: 1.14, 95%: 1.06-1.22, p < 0.001).

The difference in the seasonal patterns observed between the two species could be due to several potential factors. Both bivalve species inhabit estuaries, with large daily but also seasonal variations in salinity and temperature. However, the two species occupy different ecological niches. Soft-shell clams are sediment dwellers that can borrow up to 50 cm deep in the sand, while blue mussels form epibenthic reefs. Temperature alone seems unlikely to explain the difference between the two species. Stressful temperature conditions leading to the release of hemocytes in the water can be common for the blue mussels (Caza et al., 2020) but are unlikely to happen for the soft-shell clams because temperature variations are buffered in the sediments (Harrison and Phizacklea, 1987 ). Yet the seasonality is present for the soft-shell clams and not for blue mussels. The potential effect of seasonal variation in salinity is currently not known and remain the be investigated (but see Section 4.2 documenting how disseminated neoplasia cells tolerate a large range of salinities). Similarly, the seasonal effect of oceanic currents, tides and water column stratification on disseminated neoplasia cells dispersion is also not known. In addition, the lack of seasonality in European blue mussels may be due to the species being resistant to the disease (as observed in the pullet carpet shell Venerupis corrugate in North America, Metzger et al., 2016) , which may also explain the relatively low prevalence observed in this geographical area. To fully understand the seasonal drivers of disseminated neoplasia will require data on how the prevalence varies with environmental data at multiple spatial and temporal scales for multiple bivalve species (see, Dujon et al., 2020d) .

Climate change will increase the frequency and severity of marine infectious disease outbreaks, as well as contribute to the alignment of ideal conditions that facilitate the emergence of novel diseases (Emanuel and Fuchs, 2008; Pitcher and Forrest, 2004) , including transmissible disseminated neoplasia (Ujvari et al., 2016) . Therefore, there is an urgent need for guidelines that would facilitate the efficient detection of disseminated neoplasia across a range of environments and host species (Dujon et al., 2021) .
body_text.section: Cost and time-effective detection of disseminated neoplasia considering climate change

body_text.text: Below we detail a step-by-step procedure (based on the literature on disseminated neoplasia, as well as by following the style of guidelines used to identify diseases in terrestrial ecosystems) (for example prostate cancer, Carter et al., 2013 ; human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), Gökengin et al., 2014; malaria, Bailey et al., 2013; leishmaniasis, Paltrinieri et al., 2010) . We detail the key steps required for efficient detection of disseminated neoplasia, summarize the key diagnostic methods, compare their relative strengths and weaknesses, and finally provide a set of recommendations to aid in the prevention and mitigation of disseminated neoplasia outbreaks in the context of climate change.
body_text.section: Cost and time-effective detection of disseminated neoplasia considering climate change

body_text.text: The number of extant marine bivalves is estimated to be around 8000 (Huber, 2010) . Considering that disseminated neoplasia was detected on multiple continents (see Fig. 1a ), and that multiple independent lineages have been reported, modelling predicts that many more than the currently known six species are affected by bivalve transmissible neoplasia (Dujon et al., 2020a; Metzger et al., 2016; Ujvari et al., 2017; Yonemitsu et al., 2019) . Therefore, an a priori approach to find additional study sites and species in which the disease may be present is to focus on the coastal ecosystems in which disseminated neoplasia has already been observed within, or those with similar environmental conditions (see Section 3.2). The prevalence of disseminated neoplasia is not uniform within bivalve populations. For example, in North America the prevalence of disseminated neoplasia in soft-shell clams is maximal for a size range of 35-50 mm, which corresponds to estimated ages of 1 to years (Böttger et al., 2013) . Laboratory infection experiments also suggest that disseminated neoplasia is only able to infect soft-shell clams with a size range of 40-80 mm (Taraska and Böttger, 2013) and does not infect juveniles or older individuals. It is therefore important to sample different size classes.
body_text.section: Identifying possible sampling sites, sample sizes and the tissue to sample

body_text.text: Sample size determination is a key step to efficiently determine if disseminated neoplasia is present on a study site, and/or to accurately quantify its prevalence. Sensitivity analyses indicate that for prevalence's >5%, a sample size of at least 100 individuals is sufficient to ensure the detection of disseminated neoplasia with a probability of 0.99 on most study sites (Barber, 2004) . However, when the prevalence trends to zero the sample size required to detect the disease increases rapidly. For example, for a prevalence of 0.01, which is sometimes observed in blue mussels in Europe (Ciocan and Sunila, 2005; Sokołowski et al., 2004) , the minimum sample size required to detect the disease is 299 and 459 for a probability of 0.95 and 0.99, respectively. The sample size required to reliably estimate the prevalence (the proportion of individuals infected) at a study site is usually larger compared to the sample size required to detect the disease in at least one individual. This is especially true for intermediate prevalence values close to 0.50. In addition, the smaller the margin of error and the smaller the level of significance desired, the larger the minimum sample size that is required (Fig. 3b ). If no prior knowledge on the prevalence at a study site is available, and as a rule of thumb, a sample size of at least 100 individuals should allow the detection of disseminated neoplasia on most study sites and to obtain an estimate of the prevalence values with a margin of error of 0.10 and a significance level α of 0.05. It is also worth mentioning that these numbers only apply if the method used to detect disseminated neoplasia has a sensitivity of 1 (i.e. the test perfectly detects the disease). If the detection method produces false negatives, then the sample size needs to be increased accordingly (see for example, Cooper et al., 1982)
body_text.section: Identifying possible sampling sites, sample sizes and the tissue to sample

body_text.text: Observing the general condition and phenotype of a bivalve may indicate whether they are infected with disseminated neoplasia. Symptoms of the disease include tissue emaciation, pale digestive gland, gonadal atrophy and mantle recession, however these are not always present and these observations alone are not a robust diagnostic method (Cremonte et al., 2011) . Instead, histology and microscopy have historically been the main methods used to detect disseminated neoplasia due to their relatively low cost and reliability (but also time consuming) (Alturkistani et al., 2015) (Fig. 4) . The observed disseminated neoplasia cells are large and pleomorphic with an anomalous nucleus containing an increased DNA content (i.e. abnormally large, binucleated or abnormally shaped). The neoplastic cells will cause displacement, compression and necrosis within tissues due to disturbed apoptosis and phagocytic abilities (see Carella et al., 2013 for representative images of neoplasia in Mytilus galloprovincialis and Cerastoderma edule). While a range of cell staining methods exist, hematoxylin and eosin staining are usually employed because of its ease of use, low cost and widespread use in cancer diagnosis (Fischer et al., 2008) . Flow cytometry can also be used for the determination of cell division using fluorescent labels (Lyons and Parish, 1994) and can identify cells by separating and characterizing them depending on size, DNA content and morphology (Millán and Brunet, 2015) . In addition, the use of microsatellite markers is a time effective method to determine the presence of neoplasia by detecting the presence of alleles associated with the neoplastic cells that differ from the host cells. However, this method is inaccurate if the allele size of the microsatellite markers between the healthy and the cancerous cells are too similar. When using nuclear genes for identifying the presence of neoplastic cells, it is important to ensure that there is no duplication of the gene region (paralogues) and that the primers don't bind and amplify nonspecific regions. Samples may also require additional sequencing or separation methods (see for example Metzger et al., 2015) .
body_text.section: Detecting the presence of disseminated neoplasia

body_text.text: It is currently not known if all the cases of disseminated neoplasia observed in marine bivalves are transmissible cancers. The current best method for determining whether cancer cells are being transmitted between individuals is to find multiple genotypes within the same individual that may have arisen due to genetic differences between the host cells and the transmitted neoplasia (Metzger et al., 2015) . Specific genes can be targeted for each host species, such as the Elongation factor 1alpha 1 (EF1a1) gene in mussels (Metzger et al., 2015; Metzger et al., 2016) . A healthy individual with no neoplastic cells will contain a maximum of two alleles if heterozygous. The presence of more than two alleles and of neoplastic cells in an individual is an indication of the presence of cells that are not originally from the host and may be a transmissible cancer. The presence of one or two alleles and of neoplastic cells within an individual is an indication the cancer is a nontransmissible form. It is recommended to use multiple genes that do not contain paralogues to improve the accuracy of detection. In addition, mitochondrial genes should be avoided as bivalves mitochondria are doubly uniparental inherited and multiple haplotypes can be found within an individual, making it difficult to distinguish between parental and cancer mitochondrial haplotypes (Milani et al., 2011) . Once a transmissible cancer lineage is sequenced, phylogenetic trees (e.g. usually using a robust maximum-likelihood method) can be created to provide information about the possible origins of the cancer cell line (Fig. 4) .
body_text.section: Confirming the transmission of disseminated neoplasia

body_text.text: Since multiple environmental stressors are present in an ecosystem at the same time, they can have negative synergetic effects on individuals. Although there is much literature available on the impact of climate change on traditional infectious diseases, most are based on mathematical modelling (Fries and Mayer, 2009) . While we can extrapolate that knowledge from traditional diseases to disseminated neoplasia, aetiology and many hypotheses can be made about the effect of climate change on neoplastic cells (Fig. 5 ), we are currently lacking evidence to support them. It is therefore important to undertake in vivo studies to quantify the effect of decreasing pH and oxygen concentrations, along with increasing temperatures on the immune system of infected bivalves and how this will affect their susceptibility to the disease. In addition, it is important to monitor the prevalence of the disease in the wild in order to obtain baseline data and detailed times series that can help to mitigate the probable effects of climate change. In addition, is likely that results will differ across species due to their differing physiologies and tolerance to environmental factors (Dame, 2012) . Fig. 3 . Minimum sample size required to (a) detect disseminated neoplasia on a study site in function of the prevalence of the disease and different probability thresholds. (b) Minimum sample size required to estimate the prevalence of disseminated neoplasia on a study site based on the prevalence, a significance level α of 0.05 or 0.01, and a margin of error (MOE) of 0.10 and 0.05. Of note, the simulations assume the detection method used to detect neoplasia has a sensitivity of 1. The horizontal black lines represent a sample size of 100 individuals.
body_text.section: Complete our understanding of the global geographic distribution of disseminated neoplasia

body_text.text: This implies the presence of the disease should be tested in a wide range of species occupying different ecological niches. Antarctica currently has over 100 species of marine bivalve species (Clarke et al., 2007) , and may provide suitable study sites to determine the presence and survival of neoplastic cells in extremely low water temperatures (1°C Heise et al., 2003) . There is currently at least 400 marine bivalve species (Jablonski et al., 2013) and 158 freshwater mussel species (Seddon et al., 2011) in Africa, and studying them could provide a more complete understanding of world-wide distribution of disseminated neoplasia. Asia contains the largest global population of bivalve aquaculture (more than 85%) (Wijsman et al., 2019) with suitable study sites to investigate the effects of high population density in an aquaculture context.
body_text.section: Complete our understanding of the global geographic distribution of disseminated neoplasia

body_text.text: The use of time and cost-effective methods to diagnose disseminated neoplasia are of key importance for rapidly obtaining insights on the disease. In addition to the already established protocols (Burioli et al., 2019) , a number of promising approaches exist that could facilitate diagnosis. For example, the use of environmental DNA (eDNA) on sites with a high density of bivalves (e.g. oyster or mussel reefs) may allow for the non-invasive sampling of a population rather than individuals to determine if the disease is present. Disseminated neoplasia DNA present in the water column may be amplified using commonly used protocols (standard Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR), quantitative PCR or droplet PCR) (Mauvisseau et al., 2019; Uthicke et al., 2018) . This method is promising and was already successfully applied to detect macrobenthic species such as sea stars, as well as for marine pathogens (Peters et al., 2018 ). Another approach suggested by Caza et al. (2019) would be to use cottonbased, cellulose paper cards containing chemicals that burst cells, denature proteins and protect DNA, leaving a sample suitable for molecular identification. Those cards can be used to store many haemolymph samples for subsequent analysis in the laboratory. This type of approach would be especially suitable in developing countries where it can be difficult to have access to molecular biology laboratories. Finally, histology slides are commonly used to detect abnormal disseminated neoplasia cells. It is, however, time consuming to analyse the imagery obtained from many slides. The speed at which those imagery samples are processed can be improved by the use of machine learning algorithms (Dujon and Schofield, 2019; Kumar et al., 2015) . At the cellular level, machine learning can be trained to distinguish cancerous cells from healthy tissues (see Kumar et al., 2015) , for example by learning how to recognize anomalous shaped nucleus and we expect the use of this technique to increase in the coming years.
body_text.section: Improve the diagnostic methods to allow the rapid detection of disseminated neoplasia on multiple study sites

body_text.text: Inconsistences are present in previous disseminated neoplasia research and include variations in the methods used to detect disseminated neoplasia as well as sample collections (including sample size, location, and time of year). The effect and importance of seasonality has been overlooked and this study found there can be a wide difference between species alonealthough these results need to be validated in an experimental procedure, as sample size needs to be taken into consideration. Individual bivalve age and sexual maturity may also impact the results. As mentioned in Section 5.1, there is an age range where neoplasia is most prominent, however it is unknown if this applies to all species. If possible, age at collection and life stage of samples should be specified to aid in the conclusive determination of age as a contributing factor.
body_text.section: Understand the dynamics of disseminated neoplasia outbreaks in the wild

body_text.text: It is also unknown if the prevalence of the disease has been increasing or decreasing over the past decades (but as seen in Section 4.5 it may vary across species). To answer this question it may be possible to revisit museum collections of bivalves (e.g. University of Cambridge, United Kingdom (Museum of Zoology, 2019) contains an approximate 200type specimens of bivalves or the Queensland museum in Australia (Queesland Museum, 2019) which contains preserved samples from approximated 200 species of bivalves). Depending on preservation techniques, histological analysis and molecular analyses could confirm the presence of disseminated neoplasia across the globe. The biological route of transmission is also unconfirmed. Water filtration during feeding and cancer cell expulsion through spawning are commonly indicated as routes of transmission (Metzger et al., 2015) . However, further studies are required to determine the exact route of transmission. This information, of key importance, will aid in the conservation management and estimation of mass mortalities and disseminated neoplasia outbreaks.
body_text.section: Understand the dynamics of disseminated neoplasia outbreaks in the wild

body_text.text: Disseminated neoplasia has so far only been reported in marine ecosystems, but in a broad range of environmental conditions (see Section 3.2). This raises the question of why disseminated neoplasia, to the best of our knowledge, was not been reported in freshwater ecosystems in which similar variability is also observed (expect for salinity) and which experience the adverse effects of climate change. There are currently about 840 extant freshwater mussel species, some forming high density reefs, and which are found on all continents except Antarctica (Graf and Cummings, 2007) . We suggest two possible explanations for this pattern. While there are reports of non-transmissible neoplasms in freshwater mussels (Carella et al., 2016) , they may be simply too understudied (especially their haemolymph), and we may fail to detect the disease due to the lack of research on those species. Another potential reason is that factors underlying the emergence of a new transmissible cancer lineage in bivalves are present in the marine but not in freshwater ecosystems. This may be the case if new disseminated neoplasia lineages are initiated because of infectious agents such as virus or parasites, which are not found in freshwater ecosystems.
body_text.section: Determine if disseminated neoplasia is present in freshwater ecosystems

body_text.text: The aim of this review was to highlight the impacts of climate change on disseminated neoplasia within bivalves and to create a guideline that can be used to effectively detect disseminated neoplasia in the wild. A comprehensive literature review indicated that many environmental factors (temperature, pH and dissolved oxygen content) are likely to increase the risk of disseminated neoplasia outbreaks in marine bivalve populations. However, there was little evidence supporting that salinity will have an impact. There are still many questions left unanswered, including the extant of the geographical distribution of the disease, the dynamics of disease outbreaks and its possible occurrence in freshwater ecosystems. Therefore, it is important that further studies are conducted to enhance our knowledge of the disease in order to mitigate the potential impact on the epidemiology of disseminated neoplasia, and to prevent future outbreaks and to protect species and ecosystems with high ecological and economical value.

FIGREF0.text: (a) Location of the study sites where disseminated neoplasia was diagnosed in bivalve populations over the past 50 years. Based on the peer-reviewed literature, the prevalence of disseminated neoplasia was quantified on at least one study site in the following species: Cerastoderma edule, Macoma balthica, Mya arenaria, Mytilus chilensis, Mytilus edulis, Mytilus galloprovincialis, Mytilus trossulus and Tagelus plebeius. The black arrow indicates the crossing of a disseminated neoplasia lineage between South America and Europe described byYonemitsu et al. (2019). Red boxes indicate areas in which mortalities of bivalves associated with the presence of disseminated neoplasia in soft-shell clam for North America and a range of bivalve species in Europe (a zoom on the European red box is provided in b).

FIGREF1.text: Marginal effects (solid lines) of the seasonality on the prevalence of disseminated neoplasia in the soft-shell clam in North-East America and the blue mussel in North-West Europe. The error band represents 95% confidence interval.

FIGREF2.text: Flow diagram representing the key steps required for the detection of disseminated neoplasia and the confirmation of the cancerous cell lineages in marine bivalve populations.

FIGREF3.text: Overview of the multifactorial effects of the environment on bivalves that may lead to an increased disseminated neoplasia risk. Direction of arrows indicate the on-flow effect of climate change on bivalve physiology and environmental circumstances that may increase the risk of disseminated neoplasia outbreaks. Due to its multifactorial nature, the diagram also illustrates the need to obtain baseline prevalence data and environmental parameter time series to understand the effect of climate change on the disease. The figure is based on the following publications: (1) (Matozzo and Marin, 2011)(2)(Watson et al., 2017) (3) (Gobler et al., 2014); (4) (Sunila and Farley, 1989); (5) (Breitburg et al., 2018); (6) (Allam and Raftos, 2015); (7) (Harvell et al., 2002).
